intro: Lindernia monroi, commonly known as the Mexican mistflower, is a flowering plant native to Central America and parts of the southern United States. It belongs to the family Verbenaceae and is characterized by its delicate, fragrant flowers that bloom in spikes during the summer months. The plant typically grows in moist, well-drained soils and thrives in partial to full sunlight. Its leaves are opposite, ovate, and often have a slightly hairy texture, while its stems are slender and branching. Lindernia monroi is often cultivated for its ornamental value in gardens and as a nectar source for pollinators.
